9455784.majtheme: Urban development,Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Urban water sector reform in Senegal :
            innovative contract design to expand services to the poor

abstracts.cdata!:
In the 1990s, Senegal undertook major
            reforms of its urban water supply and sanitation (WSS)
            sector. The World Bank, which has been providing support to
            the Senegalese water sector for many years, assisted this
            reform through an International Development Association
            (IDA) credit. The water sector project resulted in
            significantly better services and financial health for the
            sector. Approximately one million extra people got water
            supply services. Social connections, changed billing
            practices, and more stand posts ensured the poor benefited
            from service expansion. Existing customers got more water of
            better quality. In addition, the utility is better run, with
            lower water losses and higher bill recovery. Keys to success
            were strong leadership and political will combined with an
            innovative institutional structure.

docna.cdata!:
Urban water sector reform in Senegal :
            innovative contract design to expand services to the poor

            Senegal : innovative contract design to expand services to
            the poor

repnme.cdata!: Senegal - Long Term Water Sector Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Long Term Water Sector
            Project for Senegal were as follows: outcomes were highly
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was highly satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: large investment programs can attract more bidders
            and the increased competition can generate cost savings that
            may be used to reinforce the impact of the project. The
            technical quality of reforms that are designed to match
            improvement of services with the financial efforts required
            from beneficiaries strengthens their social acceptability
            and prevents to a large extent political interference in
            their implementation. Effective targeting of the poor can be
            reached by using a simple eligibility criterion based on the
            location of households. Whenever country conditions cannot
            allow identifying robust income criteria at household level,
            targeting low-income neighborhoods is a good proxy. Project
            Coordination Units (PCUs) should not be assimilated to
            Project Implementation Units (PIUs). PCUs do not act as
            substitutes to Government departments or agencies and do not
            hamper capacity building; they are simply a very effective
            tool for coordinating multi-agency, multi-ministries,
            multi-donors programs.

5081774.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Long-Term Water Sector Project for
            Senegal aims to achieve sustainable improvements in
            delivering urban water and sanitation services in
            underserved and low-income areas of Dakar and secondary
            cities. There are seven project components. The first
            improves the reliability, quality, quantity, and coverage of
            water supply services by increasing production capacity to
            meet demand, increasing the number of connections,
            restructuring and balancing water distribution, and
            increasing storage capacity. The second component expands
            and reinforces drinking water networks. The third component
            increases the number of households connected to sewer
            networks, improves demand management and reduces wastewater
            and septic pollution, and limits severity and duration of
            flooding. the fourth component targets peri-urban and
            low-income settlements so as to improve sanitary conditions
            of households. This component includes an investment program
            and a capacity building and demand generation program. The
            fifth component improves the role of the executing agency in
            regulating water resources and develops an action plan for
            integrated management. The sixth component incorporates
            environmental concerns in the project to increase quality,
            and to follow safeguard policies and national regulations.
            The seventh component increases the efficiency of public
            entities involved in the water and sewerage sector by
            strengthening their capacity and the capacity of small
            private and community enterprises.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Projet d'Approvisionnement
            en Eau Potable a Long Terme : etude d'impact

abstracts.cdata!:
This Environmental Assessment addresses
            current concerns regarding potential negative impacts on the
            environment, as a result of the Long Term Water Supply
            Project in Senegal, namely, the fragility of underground
            water resources; the water supply deficit in the Greater
            Dakar area - surface water resources with multiple uses;
            and, the negligent waste water collection, and treatment
            systems - a social situation aggravated by sanitary risks,
            due to the limited access to infrastructure sanitation by
            the population. Mitigating measures include: 1) Although
            underground effluents will progressively diminish,
            benefiting the Lake Guiers surface waters, measures suggest
            monitoring and evaluation of the underground effluents in
            Dakar and the Northern region, following the temporary
            exploitation phase, and, establish formal control
            procedures, building management capacity to better service
            water resources. 2) Concerning surface waters, the creation
            of a local authority is recommended, to manage the lake
            water resources, and, establish legal, and regulatory
            frameworks to control water pollution, through an
            operational management plan, which should include costs,
            financial management, and taxation systems. 3) Waste
            disposal should be addressed in the technical specifications
            of procurement documents, emphasizing environmental
            management as it concerns, industrial pollution,
            agricultural land, and, noise, and air pollution control. 4)
            To avoid potential controversies, community consultations
            should be established, to include financial compensation for
            land losses, and, public health issues should also be
            integrated in the procurement documents.

display_title.display_title:
Sénégal – Projet
            d’approvisionnement en eau potable à long terme : étude
            d’impact (Vol. 2) : Étude d’impact (Rapport principal)
